>>3078355I have had some luck with "erection pointed up", or if they are lying down, "erection to navel", in Illustrious/Noob checkpoints. Other than that, I haven't been able to prompt directions. >>3078376It does not seem to be a concept that is trained in. I can get it to make someone pitching a baseball, but it is very wonky.

>>3078387ComfyUI has a big learning cliff. Forge/A1111 is fine for your basic image generating needs. The problem is, once you are used to A1111, it is very hard to force yourself to learn something new, especially a difficult UI. We are here for fun, after all, not work.Comfy always gets the new stuff first, though Forge is still getting regular updates. I wouldn't worry about it too much.

>>3078393Yeah the problem is I want to enhance my photo to be even more better, right now it's nice but I feel like there's room for improvement and I saw everyone else said A1111 is so limited compared to ComfyUI, feeling missing out but then I cba learning about ComfyUI lol

>>3078411For basic image generation, I don't believe Comfy has any real advantages. There are "nodes" (extensions) that Forge/A1111 doesn't really have, but that is because those addons are not widely adopted. They are not widely adopted because they don't work well or add anything useful. More does not necessarily equal better when it comes to this homebrew coding we have to deal with.Comfy is better at those 5sec gif generations people like. If you want to make those, then yes, start learning. Comfy is also better at using multiple models to work together on the same picture generation. But that is more of a niche thing that, again, is not widely adopted, especially for anime porn.Remember that A.I chat bots (like CoPilot and Grok) can help read GitHub instructions for you, and help walk you through what everything does. Not perfect, but it can help.

>>3078865So the opening post of the thread has a lot of links to get you started. Try the two online generators, they let you play around for free with registration. You can also browse what other people are posting, as it will have the information (metadata) they used to generate it. https://civitai.com/user/gtgiygushttps://civitai.com/user/YaoiBoyhttps://civitai.com/user/cg210sdhttps://civitai.com/user/Kairen92For homebrew stuff, try looking at https://www.reddit.com/r/StableDiffusion/wiki/index/ . Keep in mind you need a reasonably powerful PC in order to get it working. I have a 4060Ti with 16 gigs of vram, which is enough to run Stable Diffusion XL at full speed, which that particular barfly picture was made. You can make it work with 8 or 6 vram, but keep in mind you really should have a Nvidia card of some sort.If you run into specific questions, feel free to post them here. But it is very difficult to hand hold over 4chan threads, so give the links a shot first.Other than that, practice practice practice, and copy copy copy (what other people are doing). You will start to understand how it all comes together, but it takes time and effort.

My gens always have melty eyes. But I don't see anyone using special models or prompts to get crisp clean eyes. What's the secret?

>>3079278bad faces are from bad models/loras and also from distancethe more zoomed out the subject, the more messed up the face will beI also suspect the 'full body' tag has a negative impact on this regardless of how zoomed out it makes it due to training datayou can usually fix faces even with bad models using adetailer, if you aren't already

>>3079278>>3079282to piggyback off this comment, lots of loras suck. some for specific characters/artists are okay, but a lot are shitty and produce noise and fucked up eyes.i prefer style loras that are more general. most checkpoints know lots of characters anyways, you can check danbooru to see if the character is on there, if it is, just try generating it without a lora.adetailer helps a lot too.
>>3079269Smiling is OK. Tends to push generation younger looking. I personally prefer the serious look. "Serious" prompt also makes the overall composition more serious as well.

>>3079269Haircuts have there own prompts as well. Most all of them are associated with female characters, and will heavily influence the generator to make a female character. "Undercut" is very much male, and pushes more masculine characters. "Mohawk", "Bald/Balding", and "Dreadlock" are also male focused hairstyles that Illustrious/Noob models understands. "Asymmetrical", "Short", "Messy" and "Single Braid" are more neutral. Long, Medium, Curly, Braided, the different Bang types, as well as any hair ornaments, are very much female and will push female traits.The only thing I feel that Pony models get better than Illustrious models are Hairstyles and Emotions. Pony can do a lot of combinations of both without really pushing a gender with them. Illustrious will not.

>>3079278>>3079282>>3079285Just one more piggyback. ADetailer does not operate in a vacuum, it is not just some switch that you turn on and it makes things better.Adetailer has its own models for detection, threshold for detecting the desired object, and most importantly, it's own inpainting settings. You can even add your own sperate prompt (and negative prompt!) to help clean up the area getting detailed.Chances are, if you find a really well done, highly detailed AI generated picture, it will have been run through multiple rounds of Hires.Fix and 4-6 different ADetailer detections/inpainting. I, honestly, don't have the time or inclination to put that much work into a single picture, but it is possible.

They have a lot of active developers, UI/UX designers, customer service, marketers, wtiters, etc. They create and train their own in-house models that they're constantly improving and expanding on with new features. Electricity isn't that expensive but people are.
>>3079339>>3079314They're also committed to privacy and remaining anti-censorship, which means they can't rely on advertising or mining and selling your data like other AI platforms

But once its set up and running, a 32gvram RTX 5000 for 45 cents an hour. Will be a lot cheaper to cut out the middle man if you are willing to deal with learning the curve.

>>3079413>>3079414You don't give enough information to give you good advice.What graphics card do you have?Is everything installed on a Solid State Drive?What starting resolution?What is your upscale % and Denoising strength?How many Sampling steps, for both first gen and Hires?What Sampler method and Scheduling type?What user interface are you working with?What type of checkpoint (SDXL ; SD 1.5 ; Flux ; etc.) are you are using?What ADetailer models are you activating?How many Loras are you trying to add?All of those things change the amount of time you will need. So you have a baseline, my setup is:4060 TI with 16 gigs Vram ; Everything on SSD ; Reforge (which is no longer updated, but is about 10% faster then reg forge) ; SDXL Checkpoint (illustrious) that needs 6.5 gigs. One lora that needs 220 MiBStarting resolution of 1024*1024 with 50 steps using "DDPM" Sampling method and "SGM Uniform" Schedule type.Hires.fix at 35 steps with 0.4 Denoising strength, upscaled by 1.5* = 1536*1536 pixels 2 Adetailer models: "Anzhc Face segmant v2" and "CockandBallYolo8x".First generation @ 50 steps takes 24 sec. HiresFix 40% strength @ 35 steps takes another 42 sec. Each ADetailer detection adds about another 10 secs. It usually takes about 100 to 120 secs per picture generated.

>>3079416>>3079414>>3079413yeah i really dont want to spend money on Ai but what i like about civitai is that alot of the good artists have their own LORA so its very easy to just instantly do art from my favorite artists>>3079419im new so i have no idea i think its just generic 512 then i do the upscale function to make the faces not all deformed, usually works but it takes so long and on the website its almost instant and the faces look decent the first time

>>3079420Again, for any better advice you will have to provide more info. Screen shot of your UI would be helpful if you are really confused. I can say you are probably using an SDXL checkpoint. Try setting your starting resolution (Width and Height boxes) to 1024*1024 (or some combination thereof, like 864 * 1152 for portrait). Then, bring your Upscale percentage ("Upscale by" box) DOWN some. Upscale needs a lot more processing power than the original gen, and will slow you down if you are upscaling unnecessarily.The websites will always be faster because they have banks of GPUs to draw from. Again, keep trying to learn how to set it up yourself before giving money away. But hey, it's your life, not mine, do what you want.

>>3079413You are hitting the vram limit and by default nvidia makes it fallback to RAM, which slows things down to a crawl, search on google how to disable system memory fallback and the problem will go away, but then you will face a new problem: out of memory errors, because you are making images larger than what your gpu can do
64gb RAM is the bare minimum for image generation.
